fields.Title of Presentation: Risk Factors Associated with Pressure Injury Development Among Nursing Home Residents
fields.Description/Abstract: Purpose/Hypothesis/Aims (29)<br>The aim of this scoping review was to identify and summarize the available evidence<br>regarding risk factors associated with pressure injury (PrI) development in adult nursing<br>home (NH) residents.<br>Supporting Literature/Rationale (69)<br>Pressure injuries remain a devastating problem and NH residents have consistently<br>high rates of PrIs. Little is known about what risk factors contribute to PrI development<br>in this population and there is limited consensus about which factors influence an<br>individual’s risk. The current lack of knowledge about risk factors specific to NH<br>residents and PrI development impedes accurate PrI prediction.<br>Conceptual/Theoretical Framework (22)<br>This review was guided by the five-step framework created by Arksey and O’Malley and<br>updated by the JBI for Scoping Reviews guidelines.<br>Methodology/Interventions<br>Searches of six online databases were performed to identify papers published from<br>inception to 2024 with no language or geographical restrictions. This review was<br>reported in accordance with the PRISMA-ScR statement.<br>Analysis<br>Data analysis aimed to describe the characteristics of the included studies, and identify<br>the factors associated with PrI development among NH residents. Descriptive content<br>analysis was used to categorize and group data as well as discover knowledge gaps.<br>Results/Outcomes<br>This review included 12 studies across five countries that identified resident or facility-<br>level risk factors associated with PrI development (as identified by multivariate analysis)<br><br>among NH residents. The risk factors identified within this review varied and often had<br>inconsistent finings across studies. The majority of risk factors were resident-level<br>factors (eg., demographics, clinically assessed risk, skin status, health status) with<br>minimal evidence regarding facility-level variables.<br>Despite an extensive search of the literature for this review, our findings suggest that<br>there are few studies directly focused on risk factor identification for PrI development<br>among NH residents, highlighting the paucity of information and indicating a significant<br>knowledge gap.<br>Applicability to advanced practice nursing practice and the care of older adults<br>Pressure injury prevention begins with an individualized risk assessment including<br>identification of individualized risk factors that can be targeted and preventive strategies<br>used to reduce PrI development. As nursing staff continue to bear the responsibility for<br>PrI prevention, it is essential that healthcare providers are equipped with the knowledge<br>of risk factors to guide clinical practice. By understanding these risk factors, nurses can<br>tailor assessments, interventions, and educational efforts to prevent PrI effectively.<br>Further research is needed to improve understanding of individualized risk factors to<br>facilitate the development of evidence-based approaches to PrI risk assessment that<br>can inform personalized preventative care plans, and provide a broader exploration and<br>direction for future care delivery and research.
